author: stefanbratanov
content:
```
# Record the pending payment
    pending_payment = BuilderPendingPayment(
        weight=0,
        withdrawal=BuilderPendingWithdrawal(
            fee_recipient=bid.fee_recipient,
            amount=amount,
            builder_index=builder_index,
        ),
    )
```

What's the withdrawable epoch here by the way or am I missing sth? I assume it's set to the ssz default ZERO and later we mutate.

author: terencechain
content: i think that's right, it's not set until the payload is revealed and processed or when processing epoch and there's sufficient weight for the bid

author: terencechain
content: any luck with spec release / tests? : ) <@592004585506340885>

author: potuz
content: is the error above not resolved?

author: potuz
content: Right, as <@363800010518822915> mentioned, the withdrawable epoch is only computed when the withrawal is placed in the pending withdrawals list. The reason for this is that the churn limit has to be applied at the time in which this withdrawal is actually set.

author: potuz
content: This is set either in `process_builder_pending_payments` on epoch transition or in `process_execution_payload`

author: jtraglia
content: There was another issue lol. So many random CI issues with this release. Sorry. I restarted it about ~5 hours ago & it will skip running pytests, so it should be faster. Maybe a few hours from now if everything works.

author: jtraglia
content: We might want to deprecate the consensus-spec-tests repo eventually. It's become massive. It takes ~45 minutes to clone (with `--depth=1`) on the runner. I could publish the tarballs in the consensus-specs release. But I know some clients use consensus-spec-tests as a submodule, so I'd hate to break that flow.

author: parithosh
content: thats probably because the git runners are rate limited to not use the entire colo bandwidth, but devops should have other instance sizes and types (or you can ask them for one with higher internet speeds) if that's the bottleneck
